bibl.title: Despatch from George Strickland to James D. Porter, November 11, 1887
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gorée-Dakar, 1883-1906
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

div1.p:
Consulate of the United States,
Goree-Dakar, November 11, 1887.

Mr George Strickland
To the Department of State
Subject:
Enclosing the Testimony given by Mr. Strickland to the Examining Magistrate in the Inquest held on what is known as the "Fez Affair", with remarks.
See No. 70 of October 9, & No. 71 of October 14.
Abstract of Contents:

Reproach addressed to Mr. Strickland by Delegate of Interior Department of the Colonial Government for not covering with an envelope a letter from Captain Kent to the "Governor of Dakar" should have been made to the British Vice-Consul whom alone it concerned.
Agent of the Messageries Maritimes S.S. Company guilty of discrimination in refusing passage to a U.S. Minister.

Consulate of the United States,
Goree-Dakar, November 11, 1887.

Honorable James D. Porter,
Assistant Secretary of State,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:

I have the honor to enclose the testimony which I have this day given to the examining magistrate in the inquest which is being held following orders from Paris on the now somewhat famous "Fez affair".

With reference to the last paragraph of my deposition I would remark that Mr. Cleret, the Delegate of the Interior Department of the Colonial Government to the second arrondissement, has but recently arrived, which perhaps explains his confounding in his letter "The United States Consul on board the 'Fez' off Dakar" as he wrote on the envelope, the English Vice-Consul who was actually concerned in Captain Kent's letter, and myself who had simply handed it to Mr. Restoul.

I bet to add that it seems to me that the refusal to receive Mr Taylor on board
board the mail-steamer is a clear case of discrimination on the part of Mr. Restoul, the agent of the Messageries Maritimes line of steamships, (also a new-comer) because those steamers come from Brazil where yellow fever and cholera are endemic, whereas the "Fez" was put in quarantine simply because it is customary here at this season to inflict five days on all arrivals from the south. It follows that the passengers already on board the mail were more likely to be contaminated than the gentleman who was refused. Two days had already elapsed, and supposing Mr. Taylor to have finished the five days on shore he could not have been refused, which is absurd when it is remembered that the voyage to Europe is considerably longer. The fact is that it is a procedure quite regular to thus transfer passengers from the south, and one often effected in the case of those arriving by the "British & African" boats. Whether Mr. Restoul enjoys such limitless discretionary powers, I do not know.

I am, Sir, your obedient servant,
George Strickland,
Vice-Consul
1 Enclosure. Testimony of Vice-Consul Strickland in the "Fez affair"

Consulate of the United States
at Goree-Dakar, Senegal
November 11, 1887.

George Strickland,
Vice-Consul.

Testimony given by Mr. Strickland to the Examining Magistrate in the Inquest held at Goree following orders from Paris on what is known as the "Fez affair", before treated of in Despatches No. 70 of October 9, and 71 of October 14, 1887 from this Consulate to the Department of State.
Enclosure No. 1, in Despatch No. 73.

Testimony given by Vice-Consul George Strickland to the Examining Magistrate in the Inquest held following orders from Paris on what is known as the "Fez Affair" on November 11, 1887 at Gorée, Senegal.
Je, George Strickland, agé de 23 ans 1/2, Vice-Consul des Etats-Unis d'Amerique au Sénégal, y demeurant, in parent, ni allié, ni au service des inculpés, dépose,

Le 8 Octobre vers 8 heures 1/2 le matin, je reçus de Monsieur Charles H. J. Taylor, Ministre Resident et Consul-General des Etatis-Unis á Liberia, une lettre datée de la veille, dans laquelle il me faisait savoir que passager àbord du "Fez" et pressé d'arriver en Amerique, il désirait, on prendre le premier paquebot allant au nord, ou que le Fez pût continuer de suite sa route: il ajoutait que le capitaine de ci vapeur ayant des difficultés avec les autorités de Dakar ne pouvait reprendre la mer et était en quarantaine. Il me priait de lui procurer l'autorisation de descendre à terre a fin de profiter de la première occasion. Dans ce but j'allais faire visite à Monsieur Geoffroy, medecin principal de la marine, qui me dit que Monsieur Taylor, s'il
s'il était en quarantaine à Dakar ne pouvait descendre à terre, sans aller d'abord au lazaret, mais qu'il pouvait être transbordé sur un paquebot si le capitaine du paquebot y consentait.

Je m'embarquai ensuite pour me rendre le long du "Fez", mais à peine avais-je quitté le warf, que je rencontrai le canot de ce navire, et l'officier qui le montait me donna trois lettres en me disant que l'une était pour moi et les deux autres pour le Gouverneur de Dakar et le Vice Consul d'Angleterre. Il me demanda si les papiers du bond se trouvaient à Gorée prétendant que ce renseignment avait été donné par le port de Dakar où ils avaient été vainement reclamés; et que chaque fois que l'embarcation s'était rendue à terre, elle avait toujours été renvoyée. Monsieur Ramade le consignataire du "Fez" qui se trouvait sur le warf, en entendant cela, manifesta une grande surprise que le "Fez" eut été mis en quarantaine à Dakar alors qu'il avait été admis en libre pratique à Gorée.

Je me rendis la suite le long du bord et la Monsieur Taylor, le capitaine, Monsieur Kent
Monsieur Kent, son second et plusieurs passagers m'apprirent qu'ils étaient arrives à Gorée le 7 à 8 heures du matin, qu'après avoir été admis en libre pratique, ils s'étaient rendus sur l'avis du consignataire au pou-ton charbonier pour prendre 20 tonnes de charbon et que pendant qu'ils étaient ainsi occupés, des noirs s'étaient presentés et après avoir demandé la patente de santé avaient disparu en emportant cette pièce, qu'aucune notification de la quarantaine ne leur fut faite, et qu'ils pensaient qu'il n'y avait pas de règlements distincts pour Dakar et pour Goree; qu'après avoir terminé leur charbon, des gens du bord s'étaient rendus à l'échelle au warf pour réclamer la patente, et du linge laissé à terre lors d'un précédent voyage, et qu'on les avait chassés comme des criminels en les menaçant même d'emprisonnement s'ils debarquaient et que c'etait pourtant la première fois qu'une autorité francaise leur parlait de quarantaine; que la patente de santé ne leur avait pas été delivrée malgré la demande qui en avait été faite; et qu'à raison de cette circonstance le vapeur n'avait pu continuer sa route. Je crus
Je crus d'abord qu'il n'y avait qu'un mal entendu, et je promis au capitaine et à ces messieurs de voir le vice-consul anglais et d'arranger l'affair.

Je me rendis à Dakar et en passant à la Direction du Port, je demandai où se trouvaient les papiers du "Fez" et il me fut répondu qu'ils étaient encore chez le medecin arraisonneur. Je me dirigeai alors du coté de l’hôtel des Messageries Maritimes où loge Monsieur Restoul, Vice-Consul anglais qui est en même temps agent de cette compagnie, mais avant d'y arriver, je rencontrai un ancien domestique que je chargeai de remettre à Monsieur Restoul la lettre qui m'avait été confiée le matin et de lui annoncer ma visite. Quelques instants après ce domestique me rejoignait, tout essoufflé, et m'apprenait que Monsieur Restoul aussitot après avoir pris connaissance de sa lettre l'avait saisi au collet en le menaçant de le faire arrêter. A cause de cet incident, j'allais immédiatement chez ce monsieur, et il m'expliqua tout d'abord qu'il avait rudoyé mon domestique, pensant que c'etait un homme du "Fez"
"Fez" qui avait violé la quarantaine comme cela s'était produit déja. Il me dit aussi que le capitaine de ce navire, et les gens au bord qui étaient venus au debarcadère, avaient tenu des propos outrageants pour les autorités françaises, et qu'ils devaient de l'argent en ville: qu'il se proposait d'adresser une plainte au Foreign Office, et que le cas serait en outre soumis au procureur de la République. Je lui réponds que le capitaine se plaignait, au contraire, des difficultés que lui avait suscitées l’autorité et que pour parvenir à une entente équitable il voulait conférer avec lui. Il me dit qu'il irait à bord. Je m'en allai, mais en causant avec certaines personnes de Dakar, je remarquai que l'on était généralement indisposé contre le capitaine et les gens du "Fez".

Vers deux heures et demie, je me rendis le long du bord et je ne cachai pas mon impression à Monsieur Taylor et au capitaine, et je leur dis que l'affaire paraissait prendre une tournure sérieuse, que l'on parlait en ville d'un débarquement de passagers opéré la veille, et que mon intervention ne servirait à rien puisque le vice-consul anglais blamait lui même leur conduite
conduite. Ils me répondirent qu'ils n'avaient jamais été declarés en quarantaine, et que seul deux français étaient descendus dans la soirée après la ménace qui leur avait été faite d'etre emprisonnées en cas de debarquement. Pen après Monsieur Restoul arriva et il ent une discussion assez vive avec le capitaine. Celui-ci lui demanda meme s'il pouvait dire en sa présence qu'il ne le protegerait pas. Pendant tout le colloque, Monsieur Restoul s'obstinait a réclamer 600 francs pour des avaries faites parait il, par le "Fez" lors de son dernier passage à Dakar a des chalands de la compagnie des Messageries Maritimes. Le capitame répliqua qu'il ne paierait jamais cette somme parce qu'il n'avait commis aucune faute, et qu'il n'était pas responsable di cet accident: qu'au contraire, s'il avait souffert des avaries, il aurait poursuivi la compagnie qui ne peut obstruer une rade avec les chaines d'amarrage de ses chalands: qu'en tout cas, ou ne pouvait le retenir a Dakar pour cette raison, et qu'étant chargé d'un courrier postal belge, il ferait payer chaque heure de retard, et poursuivrait l'affaire en haut lieu
lieu pour avoir justice. De mon côté, croyant que le "Fez" serait encore sur rade au moment du passage du paquebot des Messageries (ce qui eut lieu du reste) je demandai à Monsieur Restoul si Monsieur Taylor pouvait prendre passage à bord. Il refusa d'une façon categorique en disant que le Ministre venait d'un pays contaminé et ne pouvait s'embarquer sur un des paquebots de la compagnie. A la fin Monsieur Rostoul invita le capitaine à écrire qu'il refusait de payer la somme qui lui était reclamée et lui promit à cette condition ses papiers. Le capitaine se retira un instant dans sa chambre et revint avec un papier qu'il remit à Monsieur Restoul et que celui-ci lui retourna pour être signé. En partant Mr. Restoul exigea que le canot au bord le suivit à terre pour rapporter la patente. Le capitaine fil armer son embarcation en remarquant que c'était la quatrième fois qu'il l'envoyait à terre.

Je retournai ensuite à Dakar pour des affaires personelles, et lorsque je m'embarquai pour Goree, je vis le canot du "Fez" qui attendait prés de l'eschelle. Les marins me dirent qu'ils avaient les papiers et me prièrent
prièrent de demander au Port si l'on accepterait des livres Sterling pour payer la blanchisseuse de leur linge. Je fis la commission au fils du lieutenant du port qui me répondit qu'il n'y aurait aucune difficulté. Il m'appris au meme temps que son père avait été insulte la veille par les gens du bord. Je m'embarquai ensuite et je m'arretai en route pour prevenir ces Messieurs que les papiers avaient été remis et qu'ils pouvaient appareiller. Arrivé à Gorée, ou me demanda si j'étais monté à bord du "Fez" et sur mon affirmation ou me laissa debarquer. Le surlendemain j'ecrivis à Monsieur Restoul pour lieu demander les raisons pour les quelles il avait refusé au Ministre des Etats-Unis à Liberia de prendre passage sur le paquebot des Messageries pour le cas écheant fournir des explications à mon gouvernment sachant du reste qu'il y avait des précédents et que Monsieur Taylor en parlerait; mais ma lettre est restée sans réponse.

Je termine ma déposition en protestant respectueusement contre la leçon de politesse que Monsieur le Délégué de l'Intérieur a voulu me donner: Il me reproche de n'avoir pas mis sous envelope une lettre du capitaine
capitaine Kent, que j ai bien voulu lui faire parvenir par l'intermédiaire de Monsieur le Vice-Consul d'Angleterre. Il aurait dû écrire à celui-ci qui seul avait à se charger des affaires du capitaine du "Fez", sujet anglais. J'affirm enfin que le billet lorsque il a eté remis à Monsieur Restoul n'était pas "un chiffon de papier, froissé et malpropre"
The foregoing might be briefly translated thus:
I, George Strickland, aged 23 1/2 years, Vice-Consul of the United States of America for Senegal, there residing, and being in no way connected with the persons herein involved depose,

On the morning of October 8, 1887, at about 8 1/2 o'clock, I received from Mr. Taylor, Minister Resident and Consul-General of the United States to Liberia, a letter bearing date of preceding day in which he informed me that he was a passenger on board the English steamer "Fez" and anxious to arrive in America but on account of difficulties which the ship
the ship had with the authorities at Dakar, she could not continue her voyage and was in quarantine. He desired that she might be allowed to proceed immediately or that he might land in order to wait the first northern bound mail, and engaged me to procure for him such authorization. I therefore sought an interview with the principal medical authority, Doctor Geoffrey, who said that if Mr. Taylor was in quarantine at Dakar, he could not land without going to the lazaret, but that he could be transferred directly to another ship with the consent of the captain.

I thereupon embarked to go to the steamer but had hardly left the wharf when I met a boat from the "Fez". The officer in her gave me three letters, one for me from Mr. Taylor, and the other two for the "Governor of Dakar" and the British Vice-Consul. He asked me to find out if the papers of the "Fez" were in Goree saying that such information had been given them by the Port at Dakar where they had asked for them in vain; their boat having been ordered away each time that it went to the mole. Mr. Ramade, the consignee of the
of the steamer at Goree who was on the wharf, manifested surprise and made the remark that it was curious for the "Fez" to be quarantined at Dakar when she had had free pratique at Goree.

I then went alongside the English Steamer and there I saw Mr. Taylor, Captain Kent, his officers, and several passengers, who told me that they had arrived at Goree the 7 at 8 AM where they were admitted without quarantine, and after having conferred with their consignee, they had steamed over to the coal-hulk to take twenty tons. While they were thus occupied some negroes arrived alongside and asked for the bill of health which was given up to them, and they disappeared with it on shore. No notification of quarantine was given them, and they thought that there could not be a distinct regulation for Goree and for Dakar. After having finished coaling, they went to the landing to get their papers and to find some washing which they had left on a previous voyage, but they were received like criminals and were threatened with imprisonment if they should land, notwithstanding that it was the first time that an authority had mentioned quarantine. Although they asked for their bill of health, it was
it was withheld, and for that reason the steamer could not go to sea. I thought that it was probably a misunderstanding and promised them that I would see the English Vice-Consul and arrange the matter

When I reached Dakar, I inquired at the "Direction of the Port" in passing where the papers of the "Fez" were to be found and was answered that they were still with the visiting doctor. I then directed my steps towards the house where lives Mr. Restoul, General-Agent of the Messageries Maritimes line of Mail Steamers at Dakar, and also British Vice-Consul, but before I had reached there, I met a former servant to whom I gave the letter entrusted to me for the English consul and charged him to deliver it and at the same time to announce my visit. I had gone but a little way when my man came running after me, panting and excited, and said that Mr. Restoul had seized him by the collar, handled him roughly and had threatened to have him arrested. I went immediately to see what was the matter, and the gentleman explained that he had taken my servant for some one from the "Fez" who was violating the quarantine, as some of them had already done. He further said that the
that the captain and others from the steamer had been outrageously disrespectful to French authorities and that they owed money in Dakar. He intended to complain to the Foreign Office and said that the case would be submitted to the State Prosecutor here. I replied that I came from the steamer and the captain and gentleman on board complained on the contrary of the difficulties which the authorities themselves had raised and in order to have an equitable hearing they wished to confer with him. After he had promised to go off in the afternoon, I left him but in talking with other persons of note, I observed that the people of Dakar were generally against the "Fez".

At about half past two, I went again alongside and told them that the trouble was more serious than I had supposed, that I was told that some of them had been on shore the previous night and that people were generally stirred up. I added that I could do no more because their own consul was mal-disposed towards them. They acknowledged that two passengers had been on shore but they were themselves Frenchmen and they declared that they had not been formally advised of quarantine and the threat
threat of imprisonment before spoken of was the only intimation. Here Mr. Restoul arrived, and a lively discussion took place between him and the captain in which the latter asked the former if he meant to tell him to his face that he would not protect him. During the colloquy their Vice-Consul persisted in demanding the sum of 600 francs for damage done to a coal-lighter of his company by the "Fez" on her former voyage. The captain replied that he would never pay it because the fault was not his and he was not responsible for the accident; that on the contrary, had his steamer suffered injuries, he should have claimed damages from the company which has no right to obstruct the harbor with the hidden chains of its lighters; and that in any case, he could not be stopped on his voyage for such a reason, and as he carried the Belgian mail, he should make it his business to push the matter the fartherest possible and make somebody pay every hour of his delay. For my part, thinking that from the look of things the "Fez" would be still in the harbor when the regular mail of the Messageries Maritimes which was expected should (and did)
(and did) arrive, I asked Mr. Restoul if the United States Minister could take passage on board, and he refused absolutely saying that he came from an infected country and he could not allow him on a ship of his company. In the end Mr. Restoul demanded that the captain write his refusal to pay and promised him his papers on that condition. Captain Kent withdrew in the cabin and in a moment reappeared with the paper which after being read by Mr. Restoul was returned to be signed. Upon leaving the latter required that the captain send in his boat to bring back the papers and the latter remarked that that would make the fourth time that he had already sent it for the same purpose.

I then returned to Dakar on personal business, and when I came down to the landing to reëmbark I saw the boat of the "Fez" and those in her told me that they had received their papers. They desired me to ask at the Port office if there would be any difficulty about passing the money on Shore to the washerwoman for whom they were waiting, and I therefore saw the Harbor-master's son who said that there would be none in the least. He told me at the same time
time, that his father had been insulted the day before by the people from on board the "Fez". I then started for Goree and in passing the steamer I told Mr. Taylor and Captain Kent that their papers were in their boat and that they might begin to get their anchor. Arrived at Goree, I was asked if I had been on board the "Fez" but on my affirmation was allowed to land.

On the 10th, I wrote to Mr. Restoul asking him his reasons for having toul refused the United States Minister to Liberia passage on his mail-steamer, in order that I might give explanations to my government. I was aware that there were precedents and that Mr. Taylor would bring up the subject upon his arrival. I have never received a reply of any kind.

I finish my testimony by respectfully protesting against the lesson which the Hon. Delegate of the Interior has seen fit to give me. He reproaches me for not having covered with an envelope a letter by Captain Kent of which from complaisance I served as simple carrier to the British Vice-Consul. It was to the latter that he should have written for Captain Kent is a British Subject.
